images.copyright: European river otter, Lelystad, Netherlands (© Ernst Dirksen/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The 'otter' side of life
images.caption: European river otter
images.desc: The European river otter, pictured here, is more than just an adorable face in the wild. Found across Europe, Asia and parts of northern Africa, these otters thrive in clean rivers, lakes and wetlands, serving as an important indicator of environmental health. These semi-aquatic animals are built for agility, with streamlined bodies, webbed feet and dense fur that keeps them warm even in icy waters. A single square centimetre of their fur can hold more than 70,000 hairs, making it one of nature's most effective insulators. River otters were once endangered due to pollution and habitat loss. Yet, thanks to conservation efforts, their populations are rebounding in many regions across Europe.

images.title: Endless blue
images.caption: The Great Blue Hole, Belize
images.desc: The Great Blue Hole, found near the centre of Lighthouse Reef off the coast of Belize, is one of nature's most incredible creations. This massive marine sinkhole, 318 metres across and 125 metres deep, was formed during the last ice age when a limestone cave system collapsed and rising sea levels flooded the area, leaving behind this striking natural wonder.

images.copyright: Coll d'Ares, Catalan Pyrenees (© CRISTIAN IONUT ZAHARIA/Shutterstock)
images.title: An icy border
images.caption: Coll d'Ares, Catalan Pyrenees
images.desc: For those who appreciate quiet escapes and unspoiled nature, Coll d'Ares in the Catalan Pyrenees is a perfect place to visit. Located between Molló in Catalonia's Ripollès region and Prats-de-Mollo-la-Preste in Occitania, this pass offers a breathtaking natural spectacle, especially in winter, when its landscapes are blanketed in snow.

images.copyright: Humpback whale mother and calf, Tonga (© Chase Dekker/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Protecting the giants of the sea
images.caption: Happy World Whale Day!
images.desc: On the third Sunday of February, World Whale Day highlights the beauty of whales and the challenges they face. This year, on February 16, we honour these majestic creatures, like the humpback whale pictured in today's image, known for its enchanting songs and dramatic breaches. World Whale Day began in 1980 in Maui, Hawaii, led by Greg Kauffman of the Pacific Whale Foundation, to protect humpbacks from extinction. Today, it urges global action on threats like ocean pollution, climate change and habitat loss.
images.bsTitle: Protecting the giants of the sea

images.copyright: Icicles of Misotsuchi, Chichibu, Japan (© watayu0821/shutterstock)
images.title: These are so nice-icle
images.caption: The natural ice wall of Misotsuchi, Chichibu, Japan
images.desc: Behold, the magic of the Misotsuchi Icicles in Chichibu, Japan! This breathtaking natural ice wall, over 30 metres wide and 10 metres tall, is formed by spring water freezing as it trickles down a rock face. The attraction, called 'Misotsuchi no Tsurara,' is only open from mid-January through mid-February, and includes coloured lights after dark, creating a scene that feels straight out of a winter fairy tale.

images.copyright: Two Magellanic penguins, Falkland Islands (© Vicki Jauron, Babylon and Beyond Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Look at these lovebirds
images.caption: Happy Valentine's Day!
images.copyrightonly: © Vicki Jauron, Babylon and Beyond Photography/Getty Images
images.desc: Love is in the air today: it's Valentine's Day! Across the globe, millions of flowers will be sent, and romantic restaurants will be fully booked for Valentine's dates. This day has its origins in the story of Saint Valentine, a Roman Christian who, according to legend, performed marriages for Christian soldiers who were forbidden from marrying. Just like the human lovebirds who will be celebrating today, nature also has its own romantics.

images.copyright: Lake Tyrrell, Victoria, Australia (© Monica Bertolazzi/Getty Images)
images.title: Salt of the earth
images.caption: Lake Tyrrell, Victoria, Australia
images.desc: At Lake Tyrrell, southern Australia, the sky meets the Earth in a dazzling display. The state of Victoria's largest salt lake was formed around 120,000 years ago. Over time, climate changes caused water levels to drop; these days, the lake is normally dry, except in winter when it's covered in around 5 centimetres of water. The name 'Tyrrell' comes from the local Wergaia word for 'sky,' a nod to the Boorong Aboriginal People's interest in astronomy. Spanning more than 18,180 square kilometres, Lake Tyrrell is a haven for wildlife, including Mallee reptiles, kangaroos and emus.

images.copyright: Marine iguanas, Galápagos Islands, Ecuador (© helovi/Getty Images)
images.title: Darwin's blueprint
images.caption: Celebrating Charles Darwin
images.desc: Today, we celebrate Darwin Day—a shout-out to Charles Darwin and his game-changing ideas about life on Earth. As an English naturalist, geologist and biologist, his theory of natural selection revolutionised our understanding of species, evolution and our role in the natural world. His work, 'On the Origin of Species,' published in 1859, laid the foundation for modern evolutionary biology. This day marks the birthday of Darwin and honours his genius while promoting curiosity, science and critical thinking. From thought-provoking talks to engaging exhibits, this day motivates us to keep exploring.
